review_title: Save yourself the hassle and don't even apply
job_title: Admissions in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Paid Holidays HSA/FSA Company match
cons: Toxic work environment Constant worry if you dont make your quota you will be fired Management that didn't listen Unrealistic expectations and goals New obstacles everyday to produce New goals every month HIGH Turnover rate Illegal practices

job_title: Executive Admissions Representative in Ontario, CA
pros: I liked my direct coworkers. And the pay for that position was good but it was not worth it as I found something that pays the same and is remote.
cons: I was hired with management saying they were looking to diversify the staff. Although I was constantly pulled aside and belittled for being who I am. It felt as if I was in high school and the DOA at the Ontario location was the school bully. D.V (the DOA) constantly was putting me down and other coworkers that did not fit her mold. I have worked in higher education for 8 years and for three schools. So I’m well aware of the standards that should be held, which UEI is failing to meet. Management is below standards in their handling of employees and school regulations. The type of treatment of their employees and students are degrading. At one point the DOA saying I should rush a student through the enrollment paperwork because the student has ADHD. At that point I realized I might as well be working for a car dealership instead of a college. There’s no incentives for registrations and instead of building up employees to meet their goals as other colleges do, UEI uses fear and demoralizing tactics. For those that like working here they have thrown their morals out the window. I decided to leave because morally I could not endorse this type of workplace. After having documentation showing the DOA singling employees out and giving the statement of the DOA about demeaning mental illness, HR and the campus president agreed it be best for me to not work with her. In which I decided to resign. Instead of them saying they will ensure to address the issues of the admissions department management. Overall a complete waist of time. On the other hand I have a new found appreciation for other workplaces that focus on positive culture.

job_title: Service Center Recruiter in Mesa, AZ
pros: There is not enough space here to list out all the advantages of working here. This is a really well run company, and the service center in particular is a very well run operation. The director is direct, enthusiastic, fun and fair. He is a strong leader and expects a lot out of his people, but if you deliver, you will be well taken care of here.
cons: The health insurance is a bit pricey (in my opinion) so I recommend taking your time once you are hired to explore all the benefits offered (there are a TON) before selecting the best ones for your family.

pros: Ummm? I don’t really have any pros

The COO of the company made a racist remark to me about my hair and clothing, she gave a sorry apology and stopped speaking to me. You can be doing great but the 1 time you are off and can’t meet their goals, they dismiss all of your previous hard work.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Anaheim, CA
pros: There are only a few pros which are having your own office.
cons: When interviewing they try to sell you the position as administrative, but it is mostly sales and cold calling. Lots, and lots of cold calling! This will be monitored, lots of pressure to meet monthly goals. Students are just numbers to the company, there isn't really support for them after they have signed the contract, and especially after they've graduated. The career center is undermanaged, the administrators never reach back to the students. They are also very behind in job placement. It's heartbreaking seeing most students debt themselves with thousands of dollars, being promised job placement, and leaving with only debt. The admission representatives are trained to gaslight each applicant making it seem like an interview process, and having to get accepted into the program. The reality is they will sign up anyone walking in from the street, as long as the loan goes through.

review_title: CAREER PLACEMENT OFFICER: NOT WORTH IT
job_title: Career Placement Officer in Riverside, CA
pros: Met some nice co-workers. Met some nice students and grads and was able to help them in a meaningful way.
cons: Too many to list. The environment feels like a sales job with "stand-ups", people trying to take your job leads, management rewarding abhorrent behavior, nasty attitudes (mostly management), low wages, standards are forever changing...I can say all of this and I was the #1 job developer, lol. I tried to create a different environment b/c I'm not into all of the backbiting. In the end, I left. It just wasn't worth the stress. I know of other great people who left for the same reasons. If I could give negative stars, I would.

pros: I learned how to speak with customers, learned how to use Excel in workplace, getting to answer phone calls average of 15 calls per day. The  pay is decent. Nice people to talk to and work with.
cons: My mentor looked down on me while on training and often tells me I'm bad. Didn't inspire me to do my best at all and yells at me when I make mistakes. I tried living up her expectation but it wasn't enough. Pressuring work and it is like walking on eggshells working with my mentor. With my mentor, I didn't get to do a lot. I mostly sat down doing nothing. Nothing as staring at the computer screen waiting for assignments.

review_title: Company Greed led to huge financial setbacks and layoffs which made for a volatile and stressful work environment.
job_title: Career Service Officer in Ontario, CA
pros: At this juncture I wouldn't recommend working for UEI College.  The only reason I returned to work every day was because of my immediate colleagues whom I grew to enjoy working with.  As for the leaders of the company and corporate management, I witnessed unethical practices and greed govern the decisions made by the Corporate Leaders of the company.
cons: UEI College is no longer enrolling in numerous programs due to the companies greed in enrolling as many students as possible but failing to follow through on the promise of job placement in the field of study made to students who enrolled.  As a result, UEI College is under review of the accrediting body ACCET and was forced to shut down two of their Southern California campuses.

review_title: Does not value hard working instructors

pros: The students and my fellow instructors

job_title: Registrar Department in Gardena, CA
pros: It was an honest and hard earned paycheck.

Many employees within the campus were unhappy and led to believe false hopes of success. Campus leaders would allow employees to work extremely long hours and eventually just "laid off" due to so called budgetary cuts.

review_title: The students and Colleagues made my time with UEI a Wonderful experience.

cons: Leadership did not value its employees, and there was no job security for anyone. No matter how much we did to make our students enjoy their experience in our classroom.

review_title: Not A Great Place To Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Irvine, CA
pros: The staff and instructors for the most part are good people.  They seem to get along, they welcome new employees, and they do fun little things to express their appreciation for each other.  There is a long way to go for this company to be a good functioning company, so there is a lot of potential to grow, if the administration see's your potential.
cons: The list is too numerous to cover everything in this little blurb.  First, there is no off campus access to the schools teaching portal/curriculum, this presents a problem when trying to prep for classes.  You have to go to the campus to prep, which is a second problem, they don't pay you for prep time.  You are allowed 1 hour per week for prep time, not doing anything more then just printing things from the schools portal takes longer then one hour.  The pay is the lowest in the industry, and the ridiculous rules the company comes up with are a out of touch with the classroom.  You are told to be at what is known as "stand up" at the beginning of the first break, that is 50 minutes after you start your class.  This stand up requires that you call your students to find out why they are not in class. on the surface this seems like its ok, however, if our goal is to teach our students, then this is taking away from valuable teaching time, and the students that are present are left waiting for you to call the other students.  By the time you get to a point where you should call the missing students, because you know there is no stragglers coming in, you are well into your lecture.  Further, you are told not to be on your phones, or the computer during class time, so how is it that you are supposed to make these calls if you are not supposed to use your communication equipment until the break?  The environment is one of a warehouse or a hospital, not of an educational institution.  The atmosphere is one of quantity as opposed to quality.  there

pros: Complete curriculum done, little oversight and easy to work with.  They do a lot to thank the instructors and so much so its over the top.
cons: Responsible for student issues and we don't admit the students.  The admissions of some students makes meeting obligations of the school difficult if not impossible.

review_title: It was very a rewarding experience

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Marcos, CA
pros: You truly get to help people improve their lives from time to time.
cons: Sometimes feel like your ripping people off. Like you know they would be better off at a community college, but if you don't enroll, you're not performing.

review_title: Severely Under Paid and Under Appreciated
job_title: Computer Systems Technician Lead Instructor in Chula Vista, CA
pros: 1. The students, period and nothing else.
cons:
1. Staff Complaint - Visit (or Google Map) IEC headquarters in Irvine, and then compare it a local UEI, U.S. College, Florida Career College, or anything under IEC's umbrella. Pay attention to the luxury cars headquarters at IEC, vs. the typical jalopies in the local UEI, U.S. College, Florida Career College staff parking. This should tell you how much they get paid vs. how under paid and underappreciated you will be if you work here. This should also be a note for potential students, on how much you are getting ripped off.

2. Staff Complaint - I worked at the UEI College in Chula Vista for almost 9 years. This place is ran locally with no HR department. Long story short, I had my security clearance investigator call to check if I worked there in the past (I included former supervisor's name, phone, and email, along with front desk number), and they misdirected my investigator in the wrong direction, rather than helping a former employee out.     

3. Staff Complaint – This school places so much emphasis on student attendance because they are paid $50 per hour every student is in attendance. Rather than teaching the students, there are staff training periods and actual school time dedicated towards locating these missing students. If you would rather teach, than report your numbers, this is not the place for you. Trust me, I’ve seen many good teachers get replaced because of this one thing because we are all extremely expendable with this company

3.  Student Complaint - I've never felt so guilty in my entire life. I helped this company rip-off 100s of students immediate and long-term futures by being a snake oil salesman. All of those former students are still paying outrageous loans with minimum wage jobs they could have just gotten from their own high school education or through a temp agency. Please please please do your own homework before picking up that phone or talking with the school's admission reps: 
* Read the Yelp, BBB, Glassdoor, and other Student/Consumer Complaint reviews. From my own first-hand experience, 95% of those complaints, are 100% valid.
* Visit a local UEI and find a student on the brink of graduating or going on intern/extern, and ask them if their new career job is secure (not temp or probationary) and how many of their classmates have secure jobs, as well, or at all.  
 * ~80-90% of the programs offered here are either outdated, or you do not need UEI's so-called diploma to get you the job. For example, a CompTIA A+ certificate is not enough to get your foot in the door of the IT world. Just look around your own neighborhoods and see how many customers go through a computer/ cell phone repair kiosk? Also, you can get a guard card for .016% of the price of going through UEI's Criminal Justice program.
* Find the LinkedIn accounts to your local UEI's staff. At least from what I witnessed from my 9 years of working there, a lot of the staff do not have college degrees themselves. In fact, some of the staff were former students with 1 year of working experience. You are not learning from top-tier professionals; you are learning from bench players, at best.
